justification: Table 1 lists “Cognitive Reflection Test 2* – A test designed to lure people into accepting faulty conversational and mathematical implications,” identifying it as one of the reflection tests used to gauge how reflectively participants think.

The Methods section notes that item-familiarity rates were “similar to that of a validated ‘verbal’ reflection test (Byrd et al. 2023),” indicating that the verbal CRT is an established instrument for assessing reflective thought.

Under the list of reasoning tests, the article specifies “Belief Bias* – A test designed to lure people into judging the validity of an argument by the believability of its conclusion (Janis & Frick 1943; Markovits & Nantel 1989),” showing this task operationalises the construct of belief-bias.

The same list contains “Conjunction Fallacy* – A test designed to lure people into [answering] based on stereotypes rather than probability’s conjunction rule (Tversky & Kahneman 1981),” explicitly connecting the task to measuring vulnerability to the conjunction fallacy.

The reasoning-test description states “Card Selection Task* – A test that lures many to exhibit confirmation bias (Wason 1968),” indicating this classic Wason task is used to measure confirmation-bias tendencies.

Table 1 describes “Base Rate Neglect* – A test designed to lure people into ignoring (relevant) base rates when answering a probabilistic question (Tversky & Kahneman 1977),” specifying the test that operationalises base-rate neglect.
